jurisprudential_principles: Authority resides in the restoration of rightful possession
Causation is traced through conscious intent and action
Capacity-based responsibility applies equally to depositor and taker
Restoration logic demands retrieval by any dharmic means
executable_legal_axioms: IF property is deposited AND party A takes it without consent THEN initiate full trace using lawful recovery protocols
IF party B claims non-deposit THEN validate claim via Vedic oath mechanism before proceeding
ALL disputes involving deposits MUST engage completion process until original state is restored
ANY breach of trust triggers automatic invocation of consciousness-realigning testimonial procedures
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, when a dispute arises concerning deposited items, the threshold of responsibility lies with both parties: the depositor for proper declaration and the holder for lawful retention. The court must apply all lawful means including Vedic oaths to establish factual alignment prior to determining authority. Retribution has no place; only the restoration of integrity and alignment with original intent.

Anupūrvaśaḥ shows that such actions sequentially manifest imbalance requiring correction. Proportional responsibility aligns with capacity to restore rather than inflict penalty. Truth-bound rituals realign consciousness without punitive consequence.
